DIV1.P: AS THEY ARE PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE, SMOKE-ALLEY, DUBLIN.
THE FARCE OF THE SPOIL'D CHILD; IN TWO ACTS.
AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, SMOKE-ALLEY.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT I.
SCENE.—A Dining Parlour.

SP.SPEAKER: Pickle.
SP.P: WELL, well, Sister, have a little patience and these holidays will be over; and the boy then goes back to school and all will be quiet.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Yes, till the next breaking up, no, no, bro∣ther, unless he is severely punish'd for what he has al∣ready done, depend upon it, this vicious humour will be confirmed into habit, and his follies increase in proportion with his years.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Now wou'dn't any one think to hear you talk▪ hat my son had actually some vice in him? for my art I own there is something so whimsical in all his ricks that I can't in my heart but forgive him, aye nd for aught I know love him the better into the bar∣gain.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Yes truly—because you have never been a ufferer by them—had you been rendered ridiculous as have been by his tricks as you call 'em, you wou'd ave been the first to complain and to punish.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P:
Nay, as to that, he hasn't spar'd even his father, s there a day passes I do not break my shins over tumbling-blocks he lays in my way?—why there isn't
a door in the house but is arm'd with a bason of wa∣ter on top, and left just a jarr—so that I can't walk over my own house without running the hazard of shower bath, or being wet through.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Aye, no wonder the child's spoil'd—sinc you will superintend his education yourself, you in deed.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Sister, sister—don't provoke me, at any rate I have wit enough to conceal my ignorance—I don' pretend to write verses and nonsense, as some folks do▪

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Now wou'd you rail at me for the disposi∣tion I was born with? can I help it if the Gods hav made me poetical as the divine bard says.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Made you Poetical indeed, 'Sblood. if you had been born in a street near a college, or even nex door to a day school, I shou'dn't have been surprised▪ but damn it madam, what had you to do with poetry and stuff.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Provoking ignorance!

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Hav'n't you rendered yourself the sneer of al your acquaintance by your refin'd and poetical inter∣course with Mr Tagg the author, a fellow that stroll about the country spouting and acting in every barn he comes to—and wasn't he found concealed in your clo∣set to the utter scandal of my house and the ruin of your reputation?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P:
If you had the smallest spark of taste you wou'd admire the effusions of Mr Tagg's pen, and be enchanted with his admirable acting as much as I am
—but as to this story it may serve as another sample of my nephew's sweet disposition, to coin base false∣oods against his aunt's character.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Do you tell me I can't educate my own child? and make a Lord Chancellor of him or an archbishop of Canterbury—which ever I like? just as I please?
SP.STAGE: [During the last speech Pickle leans on the table which is drawn away by a string and he falls.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: I'll lay my life that is another trick of that little mischievous wretch.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: (getting up.) An ungrateful little rascal! to serve me such a trick just as I had made an Archbishop of Canterbury of him—but as he can't be far off I'll im∣mediately correct him—here Thomas (going meets Tho∣mas who enters with table covered two plates, knives, nd forks, roasted fowl, castors, butter boat, &c.—places table between chairs and Exit.)

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: But odso here's dinner—well I'll defer my esentment till that's over—but if I don't remember his trick one while, say my name is not Pickle. (cuts p the fowl) Sister, this is the first pheasant we have ad this season—it looks well—shall I help you? they ay anger makes people dry—mine has made me hun∣gry I think—come here's a wing for you, and some of he breast.

SP.SPEAKER: Su.
SP.P: O dear Sir! O dear ma'am! my young master ma'am! the parrot ma'am—O dear!

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Parrot and young master—what the deu does the girl mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Mean! why as sure as I live that vile boy has been hurting my poor dear bird.

SP.SPEAKER: Su.
SP.P: Hurting, ma'am! no ma'am, indeed—beside I'm morally certain it was the strange cat kill'd it thi morning.▪

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: How! kill'd it, say you! but go on let's hear the whole.

SP.SPEAKER: Su.
SP.P: Why ma'am the truth is, I did but just step out of the kitchen for a moment, but in comes my young Master, whips the pheasant, that was roasting for din∣ner off the spit, and claps down your ladyship's parro ready pick'd and truss'd in its place.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: The parrot! the devil!

SP.SPEAKER: Su.
SP.P: I kept basting and basting, and never thought was basting the parrot—till just now I found the phea∣sant and all the parrot's feathers hid in the kitchen cup board.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: O my sweet, my beautiful young bird, had but just learn'd it to talk too.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: You taught it to talk—it taught you to talk you mean—I'm sure 'twas old enough—why 'twas hatched in the hard frost.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Well, brother, what excuse now? but run Susan, and d'ye hear take John, and—

DIV2.STAGE: Enter JOHN slowly, and lame, his face bound.
DIV2.P: O John here's a ine piece of business!

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Aye, ma'am sure enough.—What you've heard I see, business indeed—the poor thing will never ecover.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: What John, is it a mistake of Susan's, is it still alive? but where? where is it John?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Safe in stable an it were as sound, a made a hot mash—woudn't touch it—so crippled, will never have a leg to put on ground again.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: No, I'll sweat to that—for here's one of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: What does the fool mean? what, what's in the stable? what are you talking of?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Master's favourite mare Daisey, ma'am, poor thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: What? how! any thing the matter with Daisey—woudn't part with her for—

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Aye, aye, quite done up—won't fetch five pounds at next fair.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: This dunce's ignorance distracts me—come along Susan. [Exit with Susan.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Why what can it be? what the devil ails her.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Why Sir, the long and the short of the affair is as how—he has cut me all across the face—mercy I did not lose my eye.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: This cursed fellow will drive me mad, the mare, the mare, you scoundrel the mare.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Yes Sir, the mare—then too my shins—Mas∣ter Salve the surgeon says I must 'noint 'em wi—

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Plague o' your shins you dog, what's the matter with the mare?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Why, Sir, as I was coming home this morn∣ing over Black Down, what does I see but young Mas∣ter tearing over the turf upon Daisey, so I calls to him to stop, thof I knew your honour had forbid him to ride her—but what does he me, but smacks his whip full in my face, and dash over the gate into Stoney Lane.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Stoney Lane; well and what?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Farmer Flail met 'em, and had but just time to hide himself in the hedge before down comes mare and Master over a stone heap—and what's worse—when I rated him about it, he snatches up Tom Car∣ter's long whip, and lays me so over the legs, and be∣fore I cou'd catch hold of him he whips out of the stable and was off like a shot.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Well, if ever I forgive him this—no—I'll send him this moment back to school—school! Zounds I'll send him to sea.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Well brother, yonder comes your precious child—he's muttering all the way up stairs to himself some fresh mischief I warrant.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Aye, here he comes, stand back let's watch him—though I can never contain my passion long. (they retire.)

DIV2.STAGE: Enter LITTLE PICKLE with a kite at his back.

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: Well, so far all goes on rarely—dinner must be near ready—Old Poll will taste well I dare say—Parrot and bread sauce, ha, ha, ha! they suppose they're going to have a nice young pheasant, an old parrot is a greater rarity I'm sure, I can't help think∣ing how devilish tough the drumsticks will be—a fine piece of work aunt will make when 'tis found out, ecod for ought I know, that may be better fun than t'other—no doubt Sukey will tell and John too about the mare, a parcel of sneaking fellows, always, tell, tell, tell, I only wish I cou'd catch 'em at school once—that's all—I'd pay 'em well for't I'd be bound— here they are, and as I live my father and aunt—to be sure I'm not got into a pretty scrape now—I almost wish I was safe back at school again. (puts down the kite, they come forward.) O Sir, how d'ye do? I was just coming to—

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Come, come, no fooling, now how dare you look me in the face after the mischief you have done?

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: Mischief Sir! what mischief have I done?

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: This impudence provokes me beyond all, you know the value I set upon that mare you have spoiled for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: But Sir—hear me—indeed I wasn't so much to blame Sir, not so very much.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Don't aggravate your faults by pretending to excuse them, your father is too kind to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: Dear Sir, I own I was unsortunate, but I heard you often complain how wild and vicious Daisey was, and so, Sir, sooner than you should suffer, I was resolv'd to venture my own neck and try to tame her for you, that's all Sir;—and so I was no sooner mount∣ed but off she set—I cou'dn't help that you know Sir—and so this misfortune happen'd—but indeed Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Cou'd I be sure this was your motive, that it was merely love and regard for your old father makes you thus teize and torment him—perhaps I might be inclined—

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Yes Sir, but 'twas no love and regard for I made him beat me so.

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: John, you know, you were to blame—in∣deed Sir the truth is John was scolding me for it, and when I told him as I have told you why I did it, and that it was to hinder your being hurt, he said that was no business of mine, and if your neck was broke 'twas no such great matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: What! no great matter to have my neck broke.

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: No Sir, so he said; and I was vex'd to hear him speak so of you—and I believe I might take up the whip and give him a cut or two on the legs—it cou'd not hurt him much.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Well child, I believe I must forgive you and so shall John too—but I had forgot poor Poll; what did you roast the parrot for, you young dog you?

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: Why Sir, I knew you and my aunt were th so fond of it—I thought she'd like to see it well est—but dear aunt (to Miss Pickle) I know you must e angry with me, and you think with reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Don't speak to me—I'm not so weak as our father, whatever you may fancy.

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: But indeed aunt you must hear me, had I ot lov'd you as I do, I shou'dn't have thus offended ou—but 'twas merely my regard for your character.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Character!

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Character!—O Lord—O Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Get about your business you scoundrel.

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: Why dear aunt, I had heard that no ladies ept parrots, or lap dogs, till they were no longer able o keep lovers, and when at school I told 'em you kept parrot, the boys said, then you must be a foolish old maid.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Indeed! impudent young wretches.

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: Yes aunt, and so I resolved you shou'd no onger be thought so—for I think you're a great deal oo handsome for an old maid. (kisses her hand)

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Come Sister, saith you must forgive him—no emale heart can withstand that.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Brother I can forgive where I see occasion, but though these faults are thus excused, how will you answer to a charge of scandal and ill-nature.

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: Ill-nature ma'am—I'm sure nobody can accuse me of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: How will you justify the report you spread of my being lock'd up in my closet with Mr Tagg the author—can you defend so vile an attempt to injure my dear reputation.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: What! that too I suppose was from your care of her character—and so to hinder your aunt from be∣ing thought an old maid; you look'd her up in her closet with this author as he's call'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: Nay indeed dear ma'am—I beseech you 'twas no such thing—all I said was, you were amusing yourself in your closet with a favourite author.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: I amuse myself, in my closet with a favour∣ite author! worse and worse.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Sister, have patience—hear—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: I am ashamed to see you support your boy in such insolence—I indeed! who am scrupulous to a fault—but no longer will I remain subject to such impertinence, I quit your house Sir, and you shall quit all claim to my fortune—this moment I'll alter my will, and leave my money to a stranger sooner than to your family. [Exit▪

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Her money to a stranger! O the three per∣cents consols—O the India Stock—go child—fly, throw yourself at your aunt's feet, say any thing to please her—I shall run distracted—O those consols!

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: I'm gone Sir, shall I say he may die as soon as she pleases, but she must not leave her money to a stranger.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Aye, aye, there's a good boy; say any thing to please her, that will do very well; say she may die as soon as she pleases, but she must not leave her mo∣ney to a stranger. [Exit. Little Pickle

Well never man was so tormented. I thought when my poor dear wife Mrs Pickle died, and lest me a dis∣consolate widower, I had some chance of being a hap∣py man—but I know not how it is—I cou'd bear the vexations of my wife's bad temper, better than this woman's—all my married friends were as miserable as myself, that was some relief, but now—faith here she omes, and in a fine humour no doubt.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Brother I have given directions for my im∣ediate departure, and I am now to tell you, I will ersist in my design, unless you this moment adopt the cheme I yesterday laid down for my nephew's amend∣ent.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Why my dear sister you know there's nothing wou'dn't readily do to satisfy and appease you, but abandon my only child and take a beggar's brat in∣ my arms—impossible!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: (going.) Very well Sir, then I'm gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: But Sister stay—was ever man so used—how∣ng is this scheme of yours to last? how long am I to e deprived of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P:
How long! why till he's brought duly to effect on his bad behaviour, which nothing will induce m to do sooner than thinking he is no longer your
son, but the child of poor parents—I yesterday spoke to Margaret his old nurse, and she fully comprehends the whole affair.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: But why in addition to the quitting my own child, am I to have the torment of receiving her's—wont the sending him away be sufficient.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Unless the plot's manag'd my way, I'll have nothing to say to it, but begone, can't you tell that his distress at losing his situation, will be augmented, by seeing it in possession of another? come, come, Bro∣ther, a week's purgatory will reform him, depend on it.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Why to be sure as you say, it will reform him and as we shall have an eye upon him all the while, and Margaret was his own nurse.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: You may be sure she'll take care of him. Well since this is settled, the sooner it is done the bet∣ter. Thomas! (Enter Thomas.) send your young master here. [Exit Thomas

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: I see you're finally resolv'd and no other way will content you—well heaven protect my poor child.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Brother yon are so blinded by your foolish fondness, that you cease to perceive what is for his benefit, 'tis happy for you there is a person to direct you of my superior discernment.

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: Did you send for me aunt?

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Child come hither, I have a secret to disclose to you▪ at which you will be surpris'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: A secret Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Yes, and one that requires your utmost cou∣rage to bear, you are no longer to consider that person as your father—he is not so—Margaret who nurs'd you has confess'd—and the thing is sufficiently prov'd, that you are not his son but her's—She exchanged you when an insant for my real nephew, and her conscience at last compell'd her to make the discovery.

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: I another person's child? impossible!—Ah you are only joking with me now to see whether I love you or not—but indeed I am yours—my heart ells me I am only, only yours. (to Pickle)

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: You deceive yourself—there can be no doubt of the truth of Margaret's account.

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: Good heavens! dear Sir don't say so—I will not believe it—it can never be?—must I then give up all I respect and love to the possession of another? elieve me Sir 'tisn't the splendor of riches I repine at quitting, 'tis the happiness I never till now selt of call∣ng you father—aunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Assure yourself of our protection, but no long∣er can you remain in this house—I must not do an in∣ury to my own child—you belong to others—to them you must now go.

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P:
Yet Sir, for an instant hear me—pity me dear aunt, if yet I dare to call you so, intercede in my behalf—heaven! she knows me not. Ah! then too ure I know I am not your child—or would that dis∣tress, which draws tears of pity from them, fail to move ature in you—farewel I must away—but at least for∣give
me—pardon the faults I have committed—you cannot sure in pity deny me that—

LG.L: Since then I'm doom'd this sad reverse to prove,
To quit each object of my insant care,
Torn from an honour'd Parent's tender love,
And driven the keenest storms of fate to bear.
Ah but forgive me! pitied let me part,
Your frowns too sure would break my sinking heart.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: Where'er I go, whate're my lowly state,
Yet grateful mem'ry still shall linger here,
And haply musing o'er my cruel fate,
You still may greet me with a tender tear.
Ah! then forgive me, &c. &c.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE.—A Parlour.

SP.SPEAKER: Margery.
SP.P: AND so as I was telling your ladyship, poor little master does so take it to heart—and so weep and wail, it almost makes me cry to hear him.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Well, well, since he begins already to re∣ent his punishment shall be but short—but have you rought your boy with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Aye, have I—poor Tommy—he came from board of ship but now—and is so grown and alter'd—sure enough he believes every word I have told him as your honour order'd me—and I warrant is so sheep∣h and shamefaced—O here comes my master—he has eard it all already—
ut my lady, shall I fetch my poor Tommy to you?—e's waiting without.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: What that ill looking young rascal in the hall? e with the jacket and trowsers?

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Aye, your honour, then you have seen him?

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Seen him!—aye and felt him too—the booby met me bolt at the corner—run his curst carrotty poll n my face and has loosen'd every tooth in my head I elieve.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Poor lad—he's a sailor and but awkward as yet and so shy I warrent—but will your hoour be kind to him—

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Kind to him—why I'm to pass for his father, a'n't I?

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Aye, I wish your honour had been poo Tommy's father—but no such luck for me, as I say to my husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Indeed!—your husband must be very much obliged to you, and so am I—

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: But do, your honour, once let me see my Tommy dret in his fine smart Cloaths.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Damme! I don't half like that Tommy.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Yes, yes, you shall—but now go and fetch him here to us—I shou'd like much to see him.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Do you now madam, speak kindly to him▪ for poor boy he's quite dash'd. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Dash'd!—yes and he has dash'd some of my teeth out, plague on him.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Now Mr Pickle I insist upon your obser∣ving a proper behaviour and decorum towards thi poor lad—observe the condescension of my deport∣ment—methinks I fee a strange inclination already i his favour—perhaps I may advance him by and by t be my page, shall I brother?—here he comes—and declare as prepossessing a countenance as I ever beheld

DIV3.STAGE: Enter MARGERY and LITLLE PICKLE, as a Sailor—red hair.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Come hither, child, was ther ever such an engaging air.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Go, Tommy, do as you're bid, that's a good boy, thank his honour for his goodness to you▪

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: Be you the old fellow that's just come to be my father?

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: (aside.) Old fellow!—he's devilish dash'd to be sure—yes I am the old fellow as you call it—will you be a good child?

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: Aye, but what will you gi' me?—must I be good for nothing?

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Good for nothing! nay, that I'll swear you are already, well, and how long have you been come rom Sea, eh? how do you like a sailors life? eh?

LG.HEAD: LITTLE PICKLE.
LG.L: I am a brisk and sprightly lad,
Just come home from sea, Sir,
Of all the lives I ever led,
A sailor's life for me, Sir.
Yeo, yeo, yeo! yeo, yeo, yeo!
While the boatswain pipes all hands
With a yeo, yeo, yeo, Sir.
What girl but loves the merry tar
That o'er the Ocean roam, Sir,
In every clime we find a Port
In every Port a home, Sir, Yeo, yeo, &c.
But when our, country's fos are nigh
Each hastens to his gun, Sir,
We make the boasting Frenchman fy,
And bang the haughty don, Sir, Yeo, yeo, &c.
Our oes subdued, once more on shore,
We spend our cash with glee, Sir,
And when all's gone we drown our care,
And out again to sea, Sir.
Yeo, yeo, yeo! yeo, yeo, yeo!
And when all's gone again to Sea,
With a yeo, yeo, yeo, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: So, this is the way I'm to be entertain'd in future with forecastle jokes and tarpaulin songs—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Brother, don't speak so harshly to the poor lad—come to me, my pretty boy, I'll be your friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: Friend! Oh what your my Grand-mother—(to Miss P.) father mustn't I call her Granne?

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: What, he wants encouragement, Sister, he's found out one relation however—this boy's assurance diverts me, I like him—(aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: Granne's mortal cross and frumpish—la, father! what makes your mother there so plaguy foul weather'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Mother, indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Pk.
SP.P: O nothing at all, my dear, she's the best hu∣mour'd person in the world—go, throw yourself at her feet and ask her blessing—perhaps she may "gi' ye something." (mimics.)

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: A blessing!—I shan't be much richer for that, neither, perhaps she may give me half a crown—I'll throw myself at her seet and ask for a guinea—▪kneels) dear graune, gi' me that pretty picture (catches t it.)

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Stand off, wretch—am I to be robb'd as well s insulted.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Fie! child! learn to behave yourself better.

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: Behave myself—learn you to behave your∣elf—I shoud'nt ha' thought of you indeed—get you gone—I'm a young gemman now, and mustn't re∣member old acquaintances—get out, I say. [drives her▪off and follows.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Well, Sister—this plan of yours I hope suc∣ceeds to your satisfaction—he'll make a mighty pretty Page, sister, what an engaging air he has, Sister,—this is some revenge for her treatment of my poor boy. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: I perceive this to be all a contrivance—and this boy is taught to insult me thus—but ere long, you may repent this unparallell'd treatment of unprotected innocence. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P:
What she means to go off with her lover the player man, I suppose—but I'll watch her and her
consols too—and if I catch him in my house, it sha be his last appearance this Season—[Exit

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: There they go—ha, ha, ha! my sche has gone on rarely—rather better than their's I thin—blessings on the old nurse for consenting to it.—I' teach 'em to turn people out of doors—let me see—what trick shall I play 'em now—suppose I set the house on fire—no, no, its too soon for that—that will do very well by and by—let me see—I wish I cou'd see my sister—I'll discover myself to her, and then we might contrive something together nicely—that stair∣case leads to her room—I'll try and call her—(goes and listens) there's nobody in the way—hist, hist! Maria, Maria!—she hears me—she's coming this way—(runs and hides himself.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Sure somebody call'd me—no, there's nobody here, heigho! I've almost cried myself blind about my poor brother—for so I shall always call him—aye, and love him too—(going)

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: Maria!—Sister!—stop an instant.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: My Brother! Charles! impossible!

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P:
'Tis e'en so, faith—'twas all a trick about the nurse and child—I coax'd the old woman to con∣fess the whole to me—so borrowing this dress as you see—return'd to plague 'em a little more, that's all—now you and I must consult together how to revenge ourselves—let me see—how shall we vex 'em—I'll let
'em see who's best at plotting—what shall it be—you can't contrive to kill yourself for the loss of me, can you—that wou'd have a fine effect—is there nothing I can think of—suppose you pretend to fall in love with me and we may run away together!

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: That will do admirably, and you may depend on my playing my part with a good will, for I owe them some revenge for their treatment of you—besides ou know I can refuse you nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: Thank you a thousand times, my dear Ma∣ia—thus we'll contrive it (Seeing Pickle, they pretend to whiser)

SP.SPEAKER: Pikle.
SP.P: What!—how's this!—"Dear Maria," and ▪I'll refuse you nothing." Death and the devil! my daughter has fallen in love with that young rascal and is yeo, yeo, yeo—see too, they embrace (comes for∣ward) mighty well, young madam, mighty well, but come, you shall be lock'd up immediately, and you, young rascal, be whipt out of the house—

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: You won't be so hard-hearted sure—we will not part—here is my anchor fix'd—here am I moor'd for ever—
SP.STAGE: (Pickle endeavours to take Maria from him—She resists—And Little P. detains her by the hand)

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: (romantically) No—we'll never, never part—O cruel, cruel fate!

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: He has infected her with his assurance already—what you young minx, do you own you love him?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Love him! Sir, I adore him, and spite of yo utmost opposition ever, ever shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: O ruin'd! undone! what a wretched old m am I—but Maria! child!

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Think not to dissuade me, Sir, vain attemp no, Sir, my affections are fix'd, never to be recall'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: O dear, what shall I do! what will becom of me—Oh! a plague on my plot, I have lost m daughter, and for ought I know, my son too—Wh child, he's a poor beggar—he's not worth a sixpence▪

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P:
My soul abhors so low a thought—I despis wealth—know, Sir, I cherish nobler sentiments—
"The generous youth shall own,
"I love him for himself alone."

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: What, poety too! nay then 'tis time to pre∣vent further mischief—(pulls her) Go to your room—a good key shall ensure your safety, and that young rascal may go back to sea, with his yeo, yeo, yeo, if he will.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I obey your harsh commands Sir, and am gone—but alas I leave my heart behind.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Now Sir, for you—don't look so audacious, you young villain, don't fancy you belong to me—I utterly disclaim you.

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: (laughing) But that's rather too late now, old one, you have publicly said I was your son, and damme I'll make you stand to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: The devil! here's an affair—here John! Tho∣mas! William!

DIV2.P: Take that fellow, and turn him out of doors immedi∣ately.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: Fellow! who, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Who! why zounds! him there, don't you see im.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: What! my new young master! no, Sir, I've rn'd out one already—I'll turn out no more—

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: He's not your young master—he's no son of ine—away with him I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Su.
SP.P: No, Sir—we know our young master too well r all that—why he's as like your honour as one pea is ke another.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Aye, heaven bless him!—and may he shortly cceed your honour in your estate and fortune.—

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Rogues! villains! I'm abused, robbed—(drives ervants off) there's a conspiracy form'd against me—d this little Pirate is at the head of the gang—

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Thomas, gives Pickle a letter and Exit.
DIV2.P:
dso! here's a letter from my poor boy—this is a com∣rt indeed—well, I'll send for him home without fur∣er delay—(reads) "Honoured Sir—I heartily repent of having so far abused your goodness while bless'd with your protection—but as I fear no penitence will restore me to your favour have resolved to put it out of my power again to offend you—by bidding
"adieu to my country for ever"—here John! go, run directly to Margery's fetch home my Son, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: You may save yourself the trouble—'tis too late—you'll never bring him too, now—make as many signals, and fire as many guns as you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: What d'ye mean—

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: Mean—why he and I have changed births that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Chang'd births!

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: Aye, I'm got into his hammock and he's got into mine, that's all, he's some leagues off at sea by this time—the tide serves, the wind's fair, and Botany Bay's the word my old boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Botany Bay—then my misery is complete—unhappy Pickle—but I'll instantly see about this my∣self—and if its true—I'll come back just to blow out your brains—and so be either hang'd, or sent to Bo∣tany Bay after him. [Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE.—A Garden.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: This is the hour of my appointment with Mr Tagg—and my brother's absence is favourable indeed—well after such treatment, can he be surprised if I throw myself into the arms of so passionate an admirer—my fluttering little heart tells me this is an import∣ant crisis in my happiness—how much these vile men have to answer for in thus bewitching us silly girls—

SP.SPEAKER: Tagg.

Q.L: "My longing eyes may hope at last,

SP.P: Thus most charming of your sex, let me prostrate my∣self at the shrine of beauty. (kneels)

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Mr Tagg, I fear I never can be yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Tagg.
SP.P: Adorable, lovely, the most beautified Ophe∣lia "beautified is a vile phrase"—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Indeed, Mr Tagg, you make me blush with your compliments.

SP.SPEAKER: Tagg.
SP.P: Compliments!—"O call not by that hack|"nied name the voice of truth"—"lovely nymph O "deign to hear me—I'll teach you what it is to love."

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Love! Mr Tagg!—O moderate your tran∣ports be advised—think no more of this fatal passion.

SP.SPEAKER: Tagg.
SP.P: Think no more of it!—"can love be con∣roul'd by advice?"—"will Cupid our mother obey?"—O then consent my angel to join our hands in one—or give me my death in a frown.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Can I refuse any thing to such a lover—but y dear friend—were I to consent to our tender union—how cou'd we contrive our escape—my brother's vi∣ilance wou'd overtake us—and you might have some ause to repent of his anger.

DIV3.STAGE: LITTLE PICKLE Enters, sees them and runs off un∣perceived.

SP.SPEAKER: Tagg.
SP.P: O he's a Goth, a meer Vandyke, my love!—“but fear makes the danger seem double—say Hyme what mischief and trouble, say what men will, we∣lock's a Pill—bitter to swallow and hard of dig∣tion”—I've contrived the plot and every scene of th elopement—here in this shady blest retreat will I u fold it all—(reaches chairs) lets sit down like Jessica an the fair Lorenzo hre—(they sit.)
SP.L: "Wou'd you taste the moon ied hair,
"Since music is the food of love
"Tune our distresses and record our Woes."
SP.STAGE: [During the above speech, Little Pickle steals on behin them, sews their clothes together and runs off unsee

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: O I cou'd listen thus for ever to the cha of love and harmony—but how are we to plan o escape?

SP.SPEAKER: Tagg.
SP.P: In a low and mean attire muffled up in gre cloak will I await you in this happy spot—but wh my soul▪ why not this instant fly—thus let me sei my tender bit of lamb—there I think I had her as d as mutton (aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: No, I'm not yet equipp'd for an elop mn, nd what is of more consequence still, I hav' got with me a casket of jewels I have prepared, rath too valuable to be left behind.

SP.SPEAKER: Tagg
SP.P: (aside.) That is of some consequence indeed to me—"my diamond, my pearl," then be a good girl until I come to thee again—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Come back again in the disguise immedia∣tely—and if fortune favours faithful lovers vows I will contrive to slip out to you—

SP.SPEAKER: Tagg.
SP.P: Dispose of me, lovely creature as you please—but don't forget the casket.

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: Granne! granne!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: What rude interruption's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: O nothing at all—only father's coming—that's all—

SP.SPEAKER: Tagg.
SP.P: The devil! what a catastrophe! (both rise)

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: One last adieu! (they embrace) think you we shall ever meet again—

DIV3.STAGE: [they find themselves fasten'd together and struggle.

SP.SPEAKER: Tagg.
SP.P: Damme if I think we shall ever part—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Don't detain me—wont you let me go—

SP.SPEAKER: Tagg.
SP.P: Go! zounds! I wish you was gone.

DIV3.STAGE: [Miss Pickle runs off with the lap of Tagg's coat, which tears off—Tagg Exit—Little Pickle runs off laughing.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P:
Well, all's not so bad as I fear'd—he's not yet gone to sea, and Margery assures me I shall see him again soon, quite another thing from what he was—but now let me look after my Sister—tho' she let me play the fool, I'll take care to prevent her—I mustn't give up the consols too—but odso I haven't yet seen
my daughter,—I'll to her first, lest young yo, ye shou'd really get her shipt off—and when I've secur fifteen, I'll look after fifty—but who's coming her I'll conceal myself and watch—(goes into the arbour.)

DIV3.STAGE: Enter MISS PICKLE, with a casket.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: Mr Tagg—Mr Tagg—I hope he's return'—how tremble—kind Cupid aid your vot'ry's seeb steps—

DIV3.STAGE: Enter LITTLE PICKLE, disguised in a long cloak.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: (mistaking him for Tagg) O my dear M Tagg—take the casket, and let us make haste that w may escape before my brother comes back—

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: (Kissing her hand) This way—this way—

DIV3.STAGE: [as they are going Old Pickle comes from the arbour an stops 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Your most obedient, humble servant, madam▪well said fifty egad!—your most obsequious, Mr Alex∣ander (collars Little Pickle) what John! William Thomas! you sha'n't want attendants, mighty Prince▪(Enter Servants) or may hap you had rather sleep in castle, great Hero, we have a convenient jail close by where you'll be very safe, most illustrious chief—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss P.
SP.P: A jail! O heav'ns! poor dear Mr Tagg—victim to his love for me—Oh let's implore his fo giveness and entreat him to release you.

DIV3.STAGE: [Little Pick. kneels—thrws off his disguise and appear in his own hair, tho' still in the Sailor's dress.

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P:
Thus then let me implore for pardon, an believe that a repentance so sincere as mine will neve
ffer my heart again to wander from its duty towards im.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: What's this, my son, (embraces him) odds my eart I'm glad to see him once more—O you dear lit∣le fellow—but you wicked scoundrel, how dare you lay me such tricks?

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: Tricks! O Sir, recollect you have kindly ardoned them already, and now you must intercede or me with my aunt, that I may have her forgiveness oo, for preventing her from eloping with her tender wain, Mr Tagg.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Mr Tagg! odso! there the consols were sink∣ing apace, but you have rais'd them once more. (em∣braces)

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: And do you then indeed, Sir, sincerely for∣give me and forget all my past follies.

SP.SPEAKER: Pick.
SP.P: Forget them—ah, had you vex'd me as much gain I shou'd have been more than repaid by the hap∣piness of this moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Little P.
SP.P: Kind Sir, my joy is then complete, and I will never more offend.

DIV3.P: And yet wou'd these our fair and gracious spectators condescend to own they have been amused by my tricks, (and if I can judge of looks, or am skill'd in the language of eyes, they deign to smile assent) I shall be tempted again to transgress.
